context_evidences: - On. Jan. 7, 2009, two weeks before Barack Obama took over the presidency, the Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit in U.S. District Court under the Voting Rights Act of 1965, accusing the two men, as well as the New Black Panther Party and its leader, Malik Zulu Shabazz, of voter intimidation. The department did not believe it had grounds for a criminal case. Reference: https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/nation-world/2010/07/29/fact-check-reports-voter-intimidation-appear-exaggerated/15936860007/ published on 2010-07-29 00:00:00

- Ranking Member Smith wrote: “The Department’s continued refusal to provide any legitimate reason for the dismissal has only increased suspicions that race and politics played a role in this decision. Recent allegations from a former Civil Rights Division attorney confirm my concerns that the Justice Department has adopted a policy of race-based non-enforcement of federal voting rights laws. If these allegations are true, it means the Justice Department has become politicized and only an independent entity can effectively investigate this matter… Reference: https://judiciary.house.gov/media/press-releases/smith-calls-for-inspector-general-to-investigate-doj-handling-of-new-black published on 2010-08-03 23:59:59

- On Election Day 2008, two members of the New Black Panther Party stood outside a polling place in Philadelphia. They were dressed in uniform and yelled threatening statements and racial epithets at poll watchers. One of the individuals was holding a baton. According to long-time civil rights attorney Bartle Bull, who was at the polling station that day, it was “the most blatant form of voter intimidation” he had ever seen. Reference: https://judiciary.house.gov/media/press-releases/smith-calls-for-inspector-general-to-investigate-doj-handling-of-new-black published on 2010-08-03 23:59:59

- Perez also testified, "In July 2009, the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania declined prosecution in the matter. Our understanding is that local law enforcement officials also declined to pursue state criminal charges." Reference: https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/nation-world/2010/07/29/fact-check-reports-voter-intimidation-appear-exaggerated/15936860007/ published on 2010-07-29 00:00:00
correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. The Obama DOJ did not insist that voter intimidation was legal. In fact, the Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit against the New Black Panther Party and its members for voter intimidation. However, the case was dropped against all but one member, King Samir Shabazz, due to lack of prosecutable evidence. The DOJ did obtain an injunction prohibiting Shabazz from displaying a weapon within 100 feet of a polling place until 2012. 
https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/nation-world/2010/07/29/fact-check-reports-voter-intimidation-appear-exaggerated/15936860007/
https://judiciary.house.gov/media/press-releases/smith-calls-for-inspector-general-to-investigate-doj-handling-of-new-black
note_1_text: 2 members of the New Black Panther Party in paramilitary gear stood outside a polling place in Philadelphia in 2008. The DOJ filed a lawsuit but later  dropped the case, prompting the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights to further investigate the circumstances.    https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203550604574361071968458430    https://oig.justice.gov/reports/2013/s1303.pdf    https://www.usccr.gov/files/pubs/NBPH/docs/USCCR_NBPP_report.pdf
note_2_text: Only two Black Panthers — seen in the photo — appeared at one polling location in 2008. However, the original Tweet is correct in that the DOJ tried "to hide the extensive involvement of high-level political officials" in dismissal of a voter intimidation case against the men.    https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/28/AR2010102807129.html
queries:
1. Black Panthers voter intimidation incident
2. Obama DOJ response to Black Panthers voter intimidation
3. Legalities of observing dropboxes during voting
4. Instances of voter intimidation in US history
5. Definition and examples of mules in voting context
refute_evidences: - Therefore, the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department, which deals with all racially motivated voter intimidation cases, determined that "the facts did not constitute a prosecutable violation," according to testimony on May 14, 2010, from Assistant Attorney General Thomas E. Perez. Reference: https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/nation-world/2010/07/29/fact-check-reports-voter-intimidation-appear-exaggerated/15936860007/ published on 2010-07-29 00:00:00

- Under the Bush Administration, the Justice Department rightly filed suit against the New Black Panther Party and the two members. Despite having won a default judgment in the case, the Obama Administration abruptly dismissed several of the charges. No facts had changed. No new evidence had been found. The only thing that had changed was the political party running the Civil Rights Division. Reference: https://judiciary.house.gov/media/press-releases/smith-calls-for-inspector-general-to-investigate-doj-handling-of-new-black published on 2010-08-03 23:59:59

- The Justice Department dropped the case against all but King Samir Shabazz, saying that his display of a nightstick "supported the allegation of voter intimidation." Justice did obtain an injunction, good until 2012, prohibiting him from displaying a weapon within 100 feet of a polling place. Reference: https://www.jacksonville.com/story/news/nation-world/2010/07/29/fact-check-reports-voter-intimidation-appear-exaggerated/15936860007/ published on 2010-07-29 00:00:00

- For more than a year, Ranking Member Smith has sought answers from the Department about its sudden and unexplained dismissal of voter intimidation charges in the lawsuit against the New Black Panther Party. Reference: https://judiciary.house.gov/media/press-releases/smith-calls-for-inspector-general-to-investigate-doj-handling-of-new-black published on 2010-08-03 23:59:59
tweet_image2text: A photo of an unidentified person standing in front of a building.
tweet_text: Remember when the Black Panthers showed up with truncheons to intimidate voters and Obama’s DOJ insisted it was perfectly legal? Keep that in mind when you hear the Left go nuts over patriots peacefully observing dropboxes in case any mules show up https://t.co/SaFcmvOgfc
